data.title: 100+ Australian Slang Words to Help You Speak Like a True Aussie
data.meta_description: From sheila to brekkie, barbie and ta, here are the coolest Australian slang terms everybody needs to know.
data.text:
You don‚Äôt really know a language until you‚Äôve learned its slang. And when it comes to English, many people agree that Australian slang is the richest, liveliest and funniest slang you could learn. Sure, there‚Äôs always British English, but the Brits don‚Äôt call their barbecue ‚Äúbarbie‚Äù. And that‚Äôs a missed opportunity. Wouldn‚Äôt you agree? How can you have just a plain, dull barbecue when you could have a ‚Äúbarbie‚Äù? The Aussie slang is the best slang.

Top 10 Popular Australian Slang Terms & Words

Let‚Äôs start with the basics: core Australian slang vocabulary. Here‚Äôs a list of popular Australian slang terms you probably heard before but didn‚Äôt know what they meant.

1. Ta ‚Äì Thank you

You can also use ‚Äúthanks heaps‚Äù when you are really grateful to someone for doing something for you or ‚Äúcheers‚Äù to combine both ‚Äúthank you‚Äù‚Äå and ‚Äúgoodbye‚Äù ‚Äåin a single word. For example, ‚Äúcheers‚Äù is a perfect choice for leaving the shop after the barista gives you your coffee.

2. Brekkie ‚Äì Breakfast

Although it sounds like breakfast for kids, brekkie is the Australian meal everyone has in the morning.

‚ÄúSo‚Ä¶ what did you have for brekkie today?‚Äù

3. Barbie ‚Äì Barbecue

Well, I don‚Äôt mind if you call me a ‚Äúbarbie girl‚Äù now.

4. Crikey! ‚Äì An Exclamation of Surprise

Famously used by Steve Irwin. It‚Äôs similar to the British English slang ‚Äúblimey!‚Äù.

5. Cake Hole ‚Äì Mouth

There‚Äôs no better replacement for the word ‚Äúmouth‚Äù. Why isn‚Äôt everybody using this?

6. Ankle-Biter ‚Äì A Small or Young Child

It can also refer to a small, aggressive dog like a chihuahua.

7. Bogan ‚Äì An Uncultured or Unsophisticated Person

A ‚Äúbogan‚Äù is an uncouth or unrefined person regarded as being of low social status. The term is usually pejorative, but it can also be regarded as a joke between friends.

8. Bush Telly ‚Äì What You Watch at Night When You Are Camping

You heard ‚Äútelly‚Äù before, but ‚Äúbush telly‚Äù? That‚Äôs a new one. Basically, when you are camping, you can‚Äôt watch traditional television, so you watch the ‚Äúbush telly‚Äù: the campfire, the stars or just‚Ä¶ the bush.

9. Bikkie ‚Äì Biscuit

You‚Äôll ask for a ‚Äúbikkie‚Äù just to hear yourself say it.

There‚Äôs also the very cute expression ‚Äúto cost big bikkies‚Äù, meaning that something is very expensive.

10. Mate ‚Äì Friend

Oi, mate! This one‚Äôs a classic. You ought to use it. Additionally, you can also say ‚Äúcobber‚Äù.

Australian Slang Phrases Only Local Aussies Know

Australian slangTranslation ace! excellent, very good agro aggressive arvo afternoon Aussie salute brushing away flies with your hand avo avocado bathers/cozzies/togs swimsuit billabong a pond in a dry riverbend billy teapot bities biting insects bizzo business bloke man or guy bloody very bludger a lazy person bonzer great, awesome, first-rate booze bus police car used for catching drunk drivers bottle-o liquor shop bouncy mouse kangaroo brolly umbrella Bruce an Australian bloke Buckley's chance no hope bush forest cabbie taxi driver cactus beaten, dead, finished, not working chewie chewing gum chokkie chocolate Chrissie Christmas chuck a darkie get angry cobber friend coldie beer convo conversation crikey mikey snake dag a funny and likeable person daks trousers or pants defo definitely devo devastated dingo‚Äôs breakfast no breakfast dinkum unquestionably good or genuine dog‚Äôs breakfast complete chaos, mess esky portable cooler exy expensive fanny vagina footy football furphy erroneous or improbable story g‚Äôday! good day! grog alcohol hard yakka hard work in the nuddy naked joey baby kangaroo kindie kindergarten lappy laptop lippie lipstick liquid laugh vomit lollies sweets Maccas McDonald's mad as a cut snake very angry mozzie mosquito mushie mushroom nowt nothing oldies parents outback the vast (usually arid) interior and rural part of Australia pash a passionate kiss polly politician pressie present rightio right, ok roadie a beer you buy to take away with you roo kangaroo servo gas station she‚Äôll be right it‚Äôll be alright sheila woman or female sickie sick day sky gator airplane smoko cigarette break snag sausage sparkie electrician Straya Australia Strewth! exclamation meaning God‚Äôs truth sunbake sunbathe sunnies sunglasses tallie 750ml bottle of beer tea dinner thongs flip-flops truckie truck driver tucker food u-ey (pronounced ‚Äúu-ee‚Äù) u-turn woop woop the middle of nowhere ya you yonks a long time you beauty! fantastic, great

Funny Australian Slang Phrases

If it weren‚Äôt for this list, you‚Äôd need an Australian slang translator when you hear these Australian slang phrases! Use them in your day-to-day conversations and Aussies might think you‚Äôre one of their own.

1. What‚Äôs the John Dory?

What‚Äôs going on?

John Dory is an edible fish found on the coasts of Africa, Southeast Asia, New Zealand, and ‚Äì of course ‚Äì Australia. There‚Äôs no secret story to it apart from the fact that it just rhymes with ‚Äòstory‚Äô. So, instead of asking, ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs the story?‚Äù, in Australian slang, you ask ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs the John Dory?‚Äù.

2. Chuck a sickie

Call in sick without actually being sick.

If you ever took a day off work pretending to be sick, you‚Äôre guilty of chucking a sickie. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm chucking a sickie to go to the beach. Wanna join?‚Äù

3. Fair dinkum!

Honest, true or genuine.

Popular Australian exclamation often used to emphasize or seek confirmation (if used with the proper intonation) of the genuineness or truth of something. ‚ÄúThis pork barbie is fair dinkum!‚Äù

4. Wrap your laughing gear ‚Äòround that

Eat that.

What‚Äôs your laughing gear? Your mouth, of course. So, when you wrap your laughing gear ‚Äòround something, you‚Ä¶ eat it. It can be used in either a friendly or threatening way.

5. Carrying on like a pork chop

To behave foolishly.

Let me get my Australian slang translator for this one. üòÖ

It seems that this phrase has had a lot of variations:

Carrying on like a pork chop in Jerusalem on a Saturday.

Carrying on like a pork chop at a Jewish wedding.

Carrying on like a pork chop in a synagogue.

While the original message referred to an object that is out of place, the modern meaning has slightly shifted. So, when you hear someone using this Australian slang phrase, know that they are referring to someone who behaves foolishly, makes a fuss, complains, or rants.

6. Dog‚Äôs breakfast

Complete chaos, mess.

You can think of it this way: what does a dog‚Äôs breakfast consist of? Leftovers. Chicken bones or maybe a half-eaten pizza from last night. So, if something is really messy or disordered, then it looks like a dog‚Äôs breakfast.

7. Do the Harry

Disappear.

The complete phrase is known as ‚Äúto do a Harold Holt‚Äù, which is rhyming slang for ‚Äúbolt‚Äù. The story behind this Australian slang phrase is related to Harold Holt, the 17th prime minister of Australia. In 1967, Mr. Holt disappeared, presumably by drowning, while swimming along Victoria‚Äôs coast.

Some say he ‚Äúdid the bolt‚Äù from his responsibilities as a prime minister.

8. No worries, mate, she‚Äôll be apples

Everything will be fine.

Also known as ‚Äúshe‚Äôll be right‚Äù, these positive expressions reflect the Australian way of looking at unfortunate events. There‚Äôs no point in worrying about anything, as it will all be alright in the end.

What You Need to Know About Aussie Slang

Whether you want to move to the Australian paradise, spend a holiday there to visit the Irwin family‚Äôs Australia Zoo, or just learn the Australian slang because you feel like spicing up your English vocabulary, there are a few things you need to remember:

the term for Aussie slang and pronunciation is ‚Äústrine‚Äù;

Australian slang is often characterized by making words as short as possible but also as cute and as funny as possible!

if you want to sound like a true Aussie, you should speak through clenched teeth to stop blowflies from getting into your mouth. It sure sounds funny, but you know perfectly well that this is not entirely excluded while in Australia;

you should avoid using Australian slang in business or formal contexts because it could do more harm than good. Aussie slang is only for good friends and informal gatherings.

Before you go, let‚Äôs answer some frequently asked questions.

Crikey, mate! This language learnin‚Äô app is bonzer

Do you want to impress a bloke or a sheila with your newly acquired language skills? Well, this is your lucky day. Because with Mondly, the award-winning language learning app, you‚Äôll speak any language from day 1. It‚Äôs as fun as learning Aussie slang!

Want more? With Mondly, you‚Äôll get more every day! Quick Daily Lessons. 5 minutes a day. It‚Äôs so entertaining you‚Äôll become addicted. The best part? You‚Äôll be fluent in no time.

Get Mondly now and speak any language like you never dreamed you would!
